properties.entry:
Use the "help" command to examine specific commands:
$ {0} help help.
Command-line arguments can be placed one per line into a file, and the file can be referenced using the @ symbol:
$ echo help > file.txt $ echo help >> file.txt $ {0} @file.txt

The version command produces the following output, in order:
* The application ID (such as "com.io7m.quarrel") * The application version (such as "1.2.0") * The application build (such as "eacd59a2")
For example, for a hypothetical application named "quarrel":
$ quarrel version com.io7m.quarrel 1.2.0 eacd59a2
Show usage information for a command.

The help command provides usage information for the given named command.
For example, for a hypothetical application named "quarrel":
$ quarrel help version ... $ quarrel help help ...
The command does not accept any named arguments.
The command accepts any number of positional arguments.
The command does not accept any positional arguments.
[0, N]; Specify at least once, or use the default.
[0, N]; Specify zero or more times.
[1, N]; Specify at least once, or use the default.
[1]; Specify exactly once, or use the default.
[0, 1]; Specify at most once, or use the default.
The specified command does not exist.
The parameter expects one value, but more than one was provided.
An error occurred when trying to open/read the given file.
A parameter is missing a value.
Multiple parameters declare the same names.
No value converter is available for the parameter.
The value supplied for a parameter is unparseable.
Provide exactly one value on the command-line.
Provide a parseable value on the command-line.
Provide the right number of arguments for the parameter.
Provide a value on the command-line.
Report this bug to the application developer.
Specify the name of an existing command.
An unrecognized named parameter was specified.
The wrong number of positional arguments were provided.
The wrong number of values were provided for a parameter.
The specified command path yielded a command before all path elements were consumed.
